qas.question: Portugal modernized its public cultural facilities during what two decades?
In what year was the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation established?
Where was the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation established?
What are some examples of Portugal's public cultural facilities?

answers.text: Belém Cultural Centre in Lisbon, Serralves Foundation and the Casa da Música

qas.question: How many UNESCO World Heritage Sites is Portugal home to?

context: Portugal has developed a specific culture while being influenced by various civilizations that have crossed the Mediterranean and the European continent, or were introduced when it played an active role during the Age of Discovery. In the <a0_0>1990s and 2000s<a0_0/> (decade), Portugal modernized its public cultural facilities, in addition to the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation established in <a1_0>1956<a1_0/> in <a2_0>Lisbon<a2_0/>. These include the <a3_0>Belém Cultural Centre in Lisbon, Serralves Foundation and the Casa da Música<a3_0/>, both in Porto, as well as new public cultural facilities like municipal libraries and concert halls that were built or renovated in many municipalities across the country. Portugal is home to <a4_0>fifteen<a4_0/> UNESCO World Heritage Sites, ranking it 8th in Europe and 17th in the world.
